Issues.Title: HttpClient overloads are indistinguishable from each other in api doc
Issues.Body: # üìö Docs or angular.io bug report ### Description The signature of the overloaded methods of HttpClient is now truncated, which makes it impossible to disinguish one overload from the other. For example, the displayed signature of the first overload of get() is ``` get(url: string, options: { headers?: HttpHeaders | { [header: string]: string | string[]; }; observe?: "body"; params?: Ht...): Observable ``` and the displayed signature of the second one is ``` get(url: string, options: { headers?: HttpHeaders | { [header: string]: string | string[]; }; observe?: "body"; params?: Ht...): Observable ``` So we know that the two overloads return something different, but since the arguments are truncated, it's impossible to know what the difference is between the two overloads, which look completely identical. The textual documentation doesn't help, since it doesn't say what triggers the choice of that specific overload. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Go to https://angular.io/api/common/http/HttpClient#get, expand the overloads, try to understand what the difference between the first and the second overload is. ### What's the affected URL?** https://angular.io/api/common/http/HttpClient#get ### Expected vs Actual Behavior** Expected: the signature shouldn't be truncated. Or it should at least be able to expand it to view it completely. A textual description of what triggers each specific overload (for example, the value of the `responseType` option set to 'blob') would be a nice to have. Actual: it's impossible to view the complete signature ## üì∑Screenshot As a side note: having the most commonly used overloads listed first (i.e. the one returning `T`, and the one returning `HttpResponse`) would be nice. They're currently the 15th and the 13th one, although these are the ones documented in the HttpClient guide.

### Relevant Package
This feature request is for @angular/forms


### Description
Custom form field by implementing ControlValueAccessor missing the ability to mark untouched.

Inside this custom form field component, it has it's private formControl, handling the validation and error display, etc. If I implement this interface to make a bridge between this private formControl with the outside world formControl, there is no way I can mark that private formControl untouched to clear the error message. So I really need a setTouchedState just like setDisabledState.


### Describe the solution you'd like
Add setTouchedState method in ControlValueAccessor interface. Hopefully it's not a big change.

Not really.

```

Windows 10


### Repro steps

1. Create a PWA and use an image in CSS (e.g. as background):
```
ng new test-app
cd test-app
ng add @angular/pwa
npm install http-server --save-dev
node --print "'body { background: url(assets/icons/icon-72x72.png); }'" >> src/styles.css
```

2. Serve with ServiceWorker:
```
ng build --prod
node_modules/.bin/http-server dist/test-app -p 4200 -o
```

3. Go offline (e.g. open `DevTools > Network` and check "Offline"):

4. Reload page.

Result: There is no background :sob:


### Desired functionality
There should be background üåû
(See below.)


### Mention any other details that might be useful
Basically, the issue is that we configure the SW (in `ngsw-config.json`) to cache specific resources and make them available offline. In this case, the `/assets/**` files are configured to be cached by default. Since the CSS references an image inside `assets/`, one would expect it to be available offline without any further configuration.

Instead, the image is moved to the root output directory during the build (and renamed to include the hash) and the CSS is rewritten to look for that top-level image. This works fine as long as there is network connectivity, but the SW is not configured to cache this top-level image. As soon as the user goes offline, the image is not available any more (since the SW cannot provide it) and the nice background is gone üò¢

It is easy to fix the issue once you knwo what it is (e.g. by configuring the SW to cache the resulting file or using absolute path in CSS, which are not affected). But the problem is hard to find (e.g. usually there are no tests for how the app behaves in offline mode) and not straight forward to diagnose (i.e. you have to know about the rewriting).

@filipesilva suggested that the SW config should modified to account for the moved/renamed files.

Issues.Title: Datepicker: dateChange event returns undefined or null value when entering a date with a format of MM.DD.YYYY on Firefox browsers.
Issues.Body:
#### Bug, feature request, or proposal:
This is a bug encountered on Firefox.

#### What is the expected behavior?
When you type in a date in the format of MM.DD.YYYY, the dateChange event should an object of MatDatepickerInputEvent<D>, with the value property containing the parsed date. Expected that this is working on all web browsers.

#### What is the current behavior?
In Firefox, when you type in a date in the format of MM.DD.YYYY, the dateChange event returns an Object object, of which the value property is null or undefined.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
This can be simply reproduced by going to the angular material 2 demo for the datepicker input and change events:

Open the site on both Chrome and Firefox browsers:

In the input box as follows, enter 02.05.2018.

In Chrome, you can view the results, and the value from the event object is successfully parsed and returned:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24837926/49194028-71982e00-f3bc-11e8-8fe7-31e2fdd0ab7f.png)

While in Firefox, the input is not parsed, and the value from the event object is undefined:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24837926/49194050-8b397580-f3bc-11e8-99aa-77f98428d056.png)


#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
In my project, the version is 6.4.7. On the demo site, I would assume that it uses the latest version of Angular Material. 

Tested and it affects the latest Firefox browsers (v63.0.3).


#### Is there anything else we should know?

MM-DD-YYYY returns an undefined value in Firefox. MM/DD/YYYY works fine though.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Datepicker: dateChange event returns undefined or null value when entering a date with a format of MM.DD.YYYY on Firefox browsers." (#14319)

Issues.Title: datepicker: shows date using provided LOCALE_ID but parses date using default US locale (or a combination of them)
Issues.Body:
#### Bug, feature request, or proposal:
Bug. I don't think it is working like that on purpose.

#### What is the expected behavior?
Date picker uses provided en-GB LOCALE_ID for parsing typed in date - 27/10/2018 input manually by typing is valid 

#### What is the current behavior?
Typed date is parsed using US locale -  27/10/2018 input manually is invalid, 12/01/2018 is December, not January.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-datepicker-locale?file=main.ts

1. Select 27/10/2018 using date picker.
2. Modify the date by editing the input to 26/10/2018
3. Observe invalid input

#### What is the use-case or motivation for changing an existing behavior?
Make material datepicker great again! But seriously: it seems like if a culture is provided it should affect both parsing and formatting aspects of dealing with dates and not format it into a date which is considered invalid when updated by typing.

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
As in demo: Angular 7.1.0 Material 7.1.0. It fails validation on chrome if day (month?) is over 12, but on IE 11 is more curious as it modifies the year, I am fairly sure the swap issue causes it to work incorrectly on any browser.

#### Is there anything else we should know?
I think it may have been an issue with parsing the text date from text - it seems like it would parse using US culture ignoring provided locale.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "datepicker: shows date using provided LOCALE_ID but parses date using default US locale (or a combination of them)" (#14291)
